definitions.definition: the part of a phone that you hold close to your mouth and ear
definitions.labels: (British English)(especially North American English)(North American English)(both British English)(especially North American English)(informal, especially North American English)(British English)

examples.text: ‘It's your mother on the phone again!’, said John with his hand over the receiver.
She covered the receiver and mouthed, ‘It's him.’
He slammed the receiver down and burst into tears.
She picked up the receiver and put it to her ear.
He took a deep breath and lifted the receiver off its hook.
The receiver was dangling from the payphone.

phrases: hold the receiver to your ear
put the receiver to your ear

definitions.definition: a piece of radio or television equipment that changes broadcast signals into sound or pictures

examples.text: To change channel, select the desired number on the receiver unit.

definitions.definition: a person who is chosen by a court to be in charge of a company that is bankrupt

examples.text: They had to lay off 200 staff and call in the receivers.
The company has been put in the hands of the receiver.
A receiver was appointed by the court to handle the company’s affairs.
The company remained in the hands of the receiver.

phrases: in the hands of the receiver

examples.text: Molly's more of a giver than a receiver.

definitions.definition: a person who buys or accepts stolen goods, knowing that they have been stolen
a player who plays in a position in which the ball can be caught when it is being passed forward
